title: Jason Han
text: I’m a third-year undergraduate at UC Santa Barbara double majoring in Environmental Studies (B.S.) and Geography (B.A.). I’m passionate about restoration ecology and the process of supporting native ecosystems. Through my fieldwork, I’ve developed skills in plant identification, phenology data collection, seed cleaning, nursery care, and invasive species removal. I’ve also assisted with biological monitoring projects, trail maintenance, and horticulture work.

title: Analyzing Case Studies on Marginalized Communities
text:
It focuses on three case studies:
Lake Apopka, Florida – Farmworkers exposed to toxic pesticides experienced serious health issues, yet received little to no support during environmental cleanup efforts.
Colfax, Louisiana – A majority-Black community harmed by military burn pits and toxic emissions from Clean Harbors, a private facility operating under weak regulation.
San Joaquin Valley, California – Agricultural communities facing severe air pollution. Grassroots coalitions reframed the issue as a public health crisis to push for policy change.
The paper also discusses a research article on stormwater management, showing how factors like race, gender, and education affect willingness to engage in climate solutions. While marginalized communities often face the worst environmental risks, they also show a strong willingness to advocate for change, if given the resources and political voice to do so.

title: Steps on School Day vs Non-School Day
text:
suppressPackageStartupMessages({
  library(tidyverse)
  library(dplyr)
  library(here)
  library(gt)
  library(janitor)
})

Here I read in the data from the CSV file where I recorded my step counts. I then clean the dataset by standardizing the column names, removing missing values, and converting the step count values to a numeric format so they can be used for visualization.

steps_data <- read.csv(here("steps_data.csv"))
steps_data_clean <- steps_data |> 
  clean_names() |>  #cleans the column names to have underscores 
  drop_na() |> 
  mutate(steps = as.numeric(gsub(",", "", steps)))  # removes commas 

In this section, I summarize and visualize the relationship between daily step counts and whether it was a school day. I begin by grouping the cleaned dataset by school_day and calculating summary statistics including the sample size, mean, standard deviation, standard error, and a 95% confidence interval around the mean. I then create a jitter plot using ggplot2, which displays individual data points. The plot also includes group means as larger points and standard error bars.

steps_data_summary <- steps_data_clean |> 
group_by(school_day) |> #group data by site
  summarise( #calculating summary statistics
    n = n(),
    mean = mean(steps),
    sd = sd(steps),
    se = sd / sqrt(n),
    t_crit = qt(0.975, df = n - 2),
    ci_lower = mean - t_crit * se,
    ci_upper = mean + t_crit * se) |>
  select(school_day, mean, sd, se, ci_lower, ci_upper) |>  #only display certain statistics
  mutate(across(mean:ci_upper, ~ round(.x, 1))) #rounding those statistics

ggplot(steps_data_clean,
       aes(x = school_day, y = steps, color = school_day)) + #setting up x and y axis coloring points by site
  geom_jitter( #customizing jitter points
    position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0),
    shape = 21,
    fill = NA,
    alpha = 0.5,
    size = 2) +
  stat_summary( #adding point at group mean
    fun = mean,
    geom = "point",
    size = 3) +
  stat_summary( #adding standard error bars
    fun.data = mean_se,
    geom = "errorbar",
    width = 0.1) +
  scale_color_manual( #adding color
    values = c(
      yes = "red",
      no = "blue")) + 
  scale_y_continuous(
    breaks = seq(0, 35000, by = 5000),   # adjust max to match your data
    labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_classic() + #cleaning backgroud and removing legend
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  labs( #labeling x, y, and titles
    title = "Steps vs School Day",
    subtitle = "Jason Han",
    x = "School Day",
    y = "Average Steps")








Here, I create a summary table of the step count statistics using the gt package. It takes the calculated summary data and formats it into a table.

steps_data_summary |> #creating table using the summary data
  gt() |>
  cols_label( #renaming the columns
    school_day = "School Day",
    mean = "Mean",
    sd = "Standard Deviation",
    se = "Standard Error",
    ci_lower = "95% CI Lower",
    ci_upper = "95% CI Upper") |>
  fmt_number( #formating to one decimal
    columns = everything(),
    decimals = 1) |>
tab_header( #adding title
    title = "Steps vs School Day")

title: Why I Love My Hometown Monterey California
text:
Having grown up in Monterey, California, I’ve always been surrounded by beautiful beaches, coastal bluffs, oak woodlands, and state parks. This constant exposure to nature helped me develop a deep appreciation for the environment early on. Over time, that appreciation grew into a strong commitment in protecting and preserving natural spaces for future generations. It’s also what led me to pursue environmental studies a subject that fascinates me greatly because of the extreme relevance that it holds for today’s world.
Monterey lies along the Central Coast of California and is known not only for its scenic landscapes but also for its ecological importance. The region is part of the Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary, one of the largest protected marine areas in the United States. It’s home to an incredible diversity of marine life, from sea otters and harbor seals to migrating whales and kelp forests.
Places like Asilomar State Beach allow for access to tide pools, sandy dunes, and restored coastal habitats. Elkhorn Slough, one of California’s largest estuaries, serves as a refuge for birds, fish, and sea mammals. We also have state parks such as like Garrapata, Andrew Molera, and Julia Pfeiffer Burns State Park preserving Monterey’s beautiful coastline. These parks are amazing for hiking, wildlife observation, and reconnecting with nature.
Monterey County is also home to the Salinas Valley, a globally significant agricultural region called “The Salad Bowl of the World.” This valley produces over one-third of the leafy greens grown in the United States including lettuce, spinach, and kale. The valley’s productivity supplies local communities and food systems far beyond California. I think it’s amazing how the labels of produce across the country often says Salinas CA, which always makes me check the packaging when I’m visiting the East Coast.
Being from a place that holds both ecological, agricultural, and historical significance makes me proud and keeps me interested about how we can balance human needs with environmental stewardship. Monterey isn’t just my hometown it’s the place that continues to fuel my desire to study, protect, and live sustainably within it.

title: Resources for Environmental Studies
text:
Here are some resources I found useful that all Environmental Studies Majors should have!
Environmental Studies degrees that are offered at UCSB
Environmental Studies courses offered, the proposed courses for the year, and the syllabus from previous years of Environmental Studies courses
Nexus grades used for seeing the grade distributions of all classes over the years at UCSB
UCSB Platinum used for planning classes, better than UCSB gold
Degree requirements including GEs, Special Subject Areas, and University requirements
assist.org used for finding what classes are able to be transferred from community colleges
cvc.edu used for searching classes that are able to fulfill GE requirements by using key words in the name of certain classes


My advice:

Take as many classes that are transferable such as GEs and intro classes at a Community College.
Prioritize Environmental Studies classes that interest you, have highly rated professors, and small class sizes that fill up fast.
Take classes that cover multiple areas such as, one GE, one special requirement, and one university requirement at the same time to maximize efficiency.
Find internships early on in year one.
